By FRANK CEGELSKI
The culminating point of the annual six week rushing
'period
will be reached this Sunday between noon and two p.m.
when the
freshmen cast their bids in Levering Hall for their three
preferred
..fraternities.
At two p.m. Sunday, the ballots cast by the freshmen will
be
tabulated by an impartial group of non-fraternity men chosen by
the
Inter-fraternity Board. Bid lists submitted by the various fraternities
are matched with choices of the Freshmen. In this way, the new
men are assigned as pledges with the groups of their choice. Although
a freshman may decide to choose only one fraternity in casting his
ballot, it should be borne in mind that, in the even his frst choice
does not extend him a bid, his second and third choices may do so.
The freshmen who are required

SC Announces New
Controls On Tunnel

to go on the geology field trip
Sunday may cast their bids between 1:00 and 1:30 p.m. Sunday

Citing the four fatal accidents by appearing at the Student Counnear the University recently, Eu- cil Office in Levering Hall.
gene Zemsky, President of the Student Council, announced this week
that students caught speeding in
the tunnel under Gilman Hall will
face possible suspension from the
University.
"The tunnel is one of the most
dangerous traffic hazards on campus," Zemsky said.
He said that parking regulations
will be strictly enforced throughout the campus and all students
who haven't registered their cars
by November 14th will be fined
one dollar.
This is the first year that the
Student Council has had to place
strict controls on the tunnel, but
recently near accidents have been
reported. "This is an attempt to
close the barn door before the
horse gets out," Zemsky stated,
"and I ask students to please pay
close attention to the tunnel regulations so that we may avoid any
accidents whatsoever."
Recently cars have been speeding through the tunnel so fast that
policemen have been unable to get
the license numbers. Zemsky,
reiterating the seriousness of the
problem, said that if students are
not careful the tunnel will become
a "death trap."
The Commission announced that
students who have received tickets
for not registering their cars may
now disregard the tickets because
the new regulation allows until
Nov. 14 to register.

The rushing season actually
ends at 1:00 a.m. on Sunday, November 8, with the conclusion of
the open house rush parties at the fraternities. It is very important
to understand that the time between the end cif the open house
rush parties and the distribution
of pledge lists, to the fraternities
is a strict period of silence during which time freshmen and fraternity members may not contact
each other in any manner.
Open Rushing
At 9 p.m. this Sunday open
rushing begins. This means simply that the fraternities may extend bids to anyone who has not
accepted a previous bid from another group. Also, the strict
rushing rules which bind both
freshmen and fraternity members
during the rushing season'are no
longer in effect.
At the Hopkins, this preferential bidding system has played a
prominent role in the task of
bringing new blood into the frater(Continued on rage 2)

Country Wife
Opens Nov. 11
The Country Wife, by
William
Wycherly, will open the Playshop's
'52-'53 season Tuesday night
and
run through Saturday at the Barn,
James Byrd, director of the play
announced this week.
The play is one of the wittiest
examples of Restoration Comedy,
Byrd said. Describing it further,
he used the words "witty, bawdy,
brilliant, entertaining, good theatre, and quite sexy."
17th Century Set
The production will be in the
original 17th century period costumes and setting, Byrd added.
Peter Gray and Gloria Congleton will play the leading roles in
the drama. Miss Congleton has
been seen at Hopkins before in
Barnstormer productions.
In the supporting cast will be
Jack Silverman, Lester Wolf, Joe
Bandiera, Ruth Walsh, and Edyth
Minor. Most of the people in the
cast are connected with either
the day school or McCoy College.
Tickets selling for $1.20 for the
show are on sale at the Playshop
Office in the Barn, Gilman 4, the
main Reading Room in U11111411
Hall, and at the door.

nities. Through the years, it has
proven itself as an efficient method
by which the freshmen can make
their choices known to the fraternities, and, at the same time,
allowing the fraternities to express
their choices of the freshmen
whom..they wish to pledge.
The important part played by
the fraternities on the Hopkins
campus was expressed by Dean G.
W. Shaffer in a letter to the
Freshman Class of 1956 in which
he said, ". . . At Johns Hopkins
the fraternities have for many
years occupied a prominent position among those activities upon
which the social development of
the student has depended. Young
men who are enterLg a new and
important episode in their lives
will find in the fraternity groups
an opportunity0to share obligation
and responsibilities as well as to
enjoy special comradeship."
In September, the Hopkins' interfratrnity board published a
guide to fraternities for freshmen
in which Charles Hoffman, IFB
president, gave a further picture
of the fraternity system here.
In his open letter in the Guide he

We Need Your Head In Our
Business

stated, ". .. The graduating class
of last year left behind rank that
will be filled by your class. By
filling these vacancies you will
have the opportunity to share in
the fellowship and friendship that
has marked fraternity life at Hopkins.
"You will shortly be faced with
the decision of whetner or not you
wish to become a member of a
fraternity. Before you decide, consider fully the values offered by
fraternity membership. Fraternities provides close ties to your
school, and an unmatched opportunity to form close and lasting
friendships, as well as a place for
study and relaxation, but most
important, it brings responsibility
that you must be willing to live
up to if you join.
"I hope that I will soon be
privileged in welcoming you as a
member of one of our fraternities.
I am sure that your years at the
Hopkins and the balance of yourlife, will be enriched by membership in a fraternity of your
choice."

Du Pont's manufacturing side offers opportunity to mechanical engineers
The young mechanical engineer interested in production finds plenty
ofopportunity at Du Pont.His skills
are in great demand because so many
ofthis Company's products are made
in equipment which must operate
continuously on automatic controls.
More than halfofDuPont's M.E.'s
are currently engaged in some phase
of production work. There are three
main categories.
1. MAINTENANCE SUPERVISION. Resourcefulness and initiative are
needed in men selected for this work.
Among their many duties are the
scheduling of preventive maintenance and emergency repairs to minimize down time, suggesting equipment improvements to reduce the
maintenance load, and estimating
costs of changes or major repairs.
Normally, the supervisor establishes maintenance procedures, di-

rects transfer of personnel from one
group or area to another,and assigns
duties. He sets up office and field
work methods andcontrols the supplies of spare parts and stores.
The importance of this work is
emphasized in some Du Pont plants
where more men are needed to maintain the equipment than to operate
it. At one plant, the division maintenance superintendent, a man with
several years experience behind him,
is responsible for 1,500 pieces of
equipment and 100 miles of pipe. He
has 120 men under him, including
10 foremen.
2.PRODUCTION SUPERVISION.Other

mechanical engineers at Du Pont
use their knowledge of mechanical equipment in solving production
problems. They must see that raw
materials are on hand, that maximum yields are obtained with minimum loss,and thatthe products meet

Keeping compressors in top running condition is a typical maintenance-group problem.

3. PLANT TECHNICAL.

Other
M.E.'s at Du Pont are assigned to
the teams of plant technical men responsible for process and production
improvements. In this work, they
help solve problems on machine design,strength ofmaterials,controlinstruments, packing materials for
high-pressure equipment, etc.
Actually—in maintenance, production and development—the possibilities are almost unlimited at
Du Pont for the M.E. who likes the
manufacturing side of industry.

players would forget about it.

Homewood, Baltimore, November 7, 1952

Weight Lifters Form Club

By ROD HOHL, Sports Editor

Last Friday the Hopkins cross country team lost its second
meet of the year. Those few who have followed their exploits
for the last two seasons have wondered what happened to the
boys who had such great promise last year and now are
bogging down.
Both losses have been by the slim margin of two points against
teams that rank very well nationally. Perhaps some small change
could mean the difference between victory and defeat.
The first question that comes to mind is just why does a person
go out for cross country when he is faced with a little more than
knocking himself out on the four mile course. No member of the
team could give me an answer. No one seems to be running for
credit or glory but purely for the love of running. No crowds
sit in the stands and cheer them along except at the times they
are featured as a side show to a football game. Then a few cheer
the winners for the 300 yards of their four mile tour.
Yet, unheralded by the school at large, each year there is a
good turnout for cross country. There is definitely a high spirit
among the members of the squad which surprised me when I
learned of the conditions under which they have to train.
A team that doesn't receive its rewards for runing from the
crowd certainly should have the privilege of good meet conditions.
So far this year, however, Carl Rees, coach of the team, has been
sent on football duties each week that the gridders played away
from home.
The job of a coach at a meet away from home is particularly
Important. When the team is running on an unfamiliar course a
spotter along the way can be of great aid in winning a meet.
He can point out to the team members how they are doing in the
race and give them a quick word of advice as to how they could
pick up on the man in front of them. Without the spotters, a
runner might make his bid at the wrong time and as a result end
up one or more places lower than he could have had he had someone to give him a word along the way.
An excellent example of this was the triangular meet between
Hopkins, Haverford and Franklin & Marshall at Lancaster. Most
of the Jay squad had never run over the course before, and
with the unusually large field things were very confusing. The
other two colleges had men along the way to give their team
information but Hopkins had no one.
Another point which has been brought up recently in defense
of losing Hopkins teams is the long trip on busses that the squads
have to make before the games. The cross country team isn't even
given a small bus to ride on, but the nine man squad is jammed
into a seven passenger car and sent off.
This leaves a school like Hopkins with its policy of equal
emphasis on all sports in a very strange position. At present there
are five full time coaches in the athletic department. Of these,
four seem to be coaching football, although there are only two
football teams, the varsity and the freshman squads. At a big
university where all emphasis is put on football, and where
scholarships are offered to make sure that the team is a good one it
wouldn't make any difference whether this was true or not. However, Hopkins, at every chance .available, boasts of the way it has
perfected a program whereby each student may find a complete
sports program in whatever field he chooses be it varsity, freshman,
or intramural competition.
It seems apparent, that if what I have stated here is true,
neither the varsity nor the freshman cross country team is
getting the full attention that it deserves. Another team which also
is not getting the coaching that it should have is the freshman
soccer team. Wilson Fewster is doing an admirable job with the
varsity team as its record indicates, but he isn't a superman. He
certainly cannot be expected to handle the varsity and frosh
unassisted and do a good job with both. Out of necessity, therefore, the freshman team has been shunted off with a word of
instruction to the captains, who then, to the best of their ability,
coach the yearlings. Porto Sergio, a graduate student, who
worked out with the varsity at the beginning of the season has
been helping Fewster out with the frosh. With the heavy work
that he is forced to do in his doctorate training, however, he can
spend only a couple of days a week with the frosh.
Something should be done to correct these errors. Despite
Hopkins' small athletic budget, if the school wants its sports
program to remain truly the ideal of athletic systems, they should
spend a little money to influence a graduate student or perhaps a
former Hopkins athlete working in the Baltimore area who have
the time to come out and help with the freshman teams. As the old
maxim goes,"If a job is worth doing, it is worth doing well."

Team Begins
Chess Drills
With the preliminary tournament to decide the positions of
each member of the team out of
the way, the chess club now gets
down to the serious business of
rounding into shape for their winter season.
George Hardman, president of
the club, who won the tourney,
said he was pleased with the turnout of twenty freshmen, but cautioned, "The team is green and
will need a great deal of conditioning. In order to get this experience
we have scheduled scrimmages
with the Naval Academy and Loyola College in the next two
weeks."
Hardman, who has been the star
of the team with his great board
work, defeated William Landis in
the Hopkins Open Chess tourney
by a 4%..'/ to 4-1 margin. Neither
man lost, but Landis tied twice
whereas Hardman was held even
only once.
Last year the team had only a
mediocre season, breaking even in
twenty matches, but the Jays finished third in the Maryland Chess
Federation.
Hardman, as the team's number
one board, has obtained individual
laurels. Last year he was one of
three people to draw with international grand master Samuel Reshevsky. Later in the year the
Hopkins ace defeated the Maryland State Champion in a non-title
bout and is looking for a return
go this year for the crown.

By FRANK CEGELSKI
The culminating point of the annual six week rushing
'period
will be reached this Sunday between noon and two p.m.
when the
freshmen cast their bids in Levering Hall for their three
preferred
..fraternities.
At two p.m. Sunday, the ballots cast by the freshmen will
be
tabulated by an impartial group of non-fraternity men chosen by
the
Inter-fraternity Board. Bid lists submitted by the various fraternities
are matched with choices of the Freshmen. In this way, the new
men are assigned as pledges with the groups of their choice. Although
a freshman may decide to choose only one fraternity in casting his
ballot, it should be borne in mind that, in the even his frst choice
does not extend him a bid, his second and third choices may do so.
The freshmen who are required

SC Announces New
Controls On Tunnel

to go on the geology field trip
Sunday may cast their bids between 1:00 and 1:30 p.m. Sunday

Citing the four fatal accidents by appearing at the Student Counnear the University recently, Eu- cil Office in Levering Hall.
gene Zemsky, President of the Student Council, announced this week
that students caught speeding in
the tunnel under Gilman Hall will
face possible suspension from the
University.
"The tunnel is one of the most
dangerous traffic hazards on campus," Zemsky said.
He said that parking regulations
will be strictly enforced throughout the campus and all students
who haven't registered their cars
by November 14th will be fined
one dollar.
This is the first year that the
Student Council has had to place
strict controls on the tunnel, but
recently near accidents have been
reported. "This is an attempt to
close the barn door before the
horse gets out," Zemsky stated,
"and I ask students to please pay
close attention to the tunnel regulations so that we may avoid any
accidents whatsoever."
Recently cars have been speeding through the tunnel so fast that
policemen have been unable to get
the license numbers. Zemsky,
reiterating the seriousness of the
problem, said that if students are
not careful the tunnel will become
a "death trap."
The Commission announced that
students who have received tickets
for not registering their cars may
now disregard the tickets because
the new regulation allows until
Nov. 14 to register.

Du Pont's manufacturing side offers opportunity to mechanical engineers
The young mechanical engineer interested in production finds plenty
ofopportunity at Du Pont.His skills
are in great demand because so many
ofthis Company's products are made
in equipment which must operate
continuously on automatic controls.
More than halfofDuPont's M.E.'s
are currently engaged in some phase
of production work. There are three
main categories.
1. MAINTENANCE SUPERVISION. Resourcefulness and initiative are
needed in men selected for this work.
Among their many duties are the
scheduling of preventive maintenance and emergency repairs to minimize down time, suggesting equipment improvements to reduce the
maintenance load, and estimating
costs of changes or major repairs.
Normally, the supervisor establishes maintenance procedures, di-

rects transfer of personnel from one
group or area to another,and assigns
duties. He sets up office and field
work methods andcontrols the supplies of spare parts and stores.
The importance of this work is
emphasized in some Du Pont plants
where more men are needed to maintain the equipment than to operate
it. At one plant, the division maintenance superintendent, a man with
several years experience behind him,
is responsible for 1,500 pieces of
equipment and 100 miles of pipe. He
has 120 men under him, including
10 foremen.
2.PRODUCTION SUPERVISION.Other

mechanical engineers at Du Pont
use their knowledge of mechanical equipment in solving production
problems. They must see that raw
materials are on hand, that maximum yields are obtained with minimum loss,and thatthe products meet

Keeping compressors in top running condition is a typical maintenance-group problem.

3. PLANT TECHNICAL.

Other
M.E.'s at Du Pont are assigned to
the teams of plant technical men responsible for process and production
improvements. In this work, they
help solve problems on machine design,strength ofmaterials,controlinstruments, packing materials for
high-pressure equipment, etc.
Actually—in maintenance, production and development—the possibilities are almost unlimited at
Du Pont for the M.E. who likes the
manufacturing side of industry.

Homewood, Baltimore, November 7, 1952

Weight Lifters Form Club

By ROD HOHL, Sports Editor

Last Friday the Hopkins cross country team lost its second
meet of the year. Those few who have followed their exploits
for the last two seasons have wondered what happened to the
boys who had such great promise last year and now are
bogging down.
Both losses have been by the slim margin of two points against
teams that rank very well nationally. Perhaps some small change
could mean the difference between victory and defeat.
The first question that comes to mind is just why does a person
go out for cross country when he is faced with a little more than
knocking himself out on the four mile course. No member of the
team could give me an answer. No one seems to be running for
credit or glory but purely for the love of running. No crowds
sit in the stands and cheer them along except at the times they
are featured as a side show to a football game. Then a few cheer
the winners for the 300 yards of their four mile tour.
Yet, unheralded by the school at large, each year there is a
good turnout for cross country. There is definitely a high spirit
among the members of the squad which surprised me when I
learned of the conditions under which they have to train.
A team that doesn't receive its rewards for runing from the
crowd certainly should have the privilege of good meet conditions.
So far this year, however, Carl Rees, coach of the team, has been
sent on football duties each week that the gridders played away
from home.
The job of a coach at a meet away from home is particularly
Important. When the team is running on an unfamiliar course a
spotter along the way can be of great aid in winning a meet.
He can point out to the team members how they are doing in the
race and give them a quick word of advice as to how they could
pick up on the man in front of them. Without the spotters, a
runner might make his bid at the wrong time and as a result end
up one or more places lower than he could have had he had someone to give him a word along the way.
An excellent example of this was the triangular meet between
Hopkins, Haverford and Franklin & Marshall at Lancaster. Most
of the Jay squad had never run over the course before, and
with the unusually large field things were very confusing. The
other two colleges had men along the way to give their team
information but Hopkins had no one.
Another point which has been brought up recently in defense
of losing Hopkins teams is the long trip on busses that the squads
have to make before the games. The cross country team isn't even
given a small bus to ride on, but the nine man squad is jammed
into a seven passenger car and sent off.
This leaves a school like Hopkins with its policy of equal
emphasis on all sports in a very strange position. At present there
are five full time coaches in the athletic department. Of these,
four seem to be coaching football, although there are only two
football teams, the varsity and the freshman squads. At a big
university where all emphasis is put on football, and where
scholarships are offered to make sure that the team is a good one it
wouldn't make any difference whether this was true or not. However, Hopkins, at every chance .available, boasts of the way it has
perfected a program whereby each student may find a complete
sports program in whatever field he chooses be it varsity, freshman,
or intramural competition.
It seems apparent, that if what I have stated here is true,
neither the varsity nor the freshman cross country team is
getting the full attention that it deserves. Another team which also
is not getting the coaching that it should have is the freshman
soccer team. Wilson Fewster is doing an admirable job with the
varsity team as its record indicates, but he isn't a superman. He
certainly cannot be expected to handle the varsity and frosh
unassisted and do a good job with both. Out of necessity, therefore, the freshman team has been shunted off with a word of
instruction to the captains, who then, to the best of their ability,
coach the yearlings. Porto Sergio, a graduate student, who
worked out with the varsity at the beginning of the season has
been helping Fewster out with the frosh. With the heavy work
that he is forced to do in his doctorate training, however, he can
spend only a couple of days a week with the frosh.
Something should be done to correct these errors. Despite
Hopkins' small athletic budget, if the school wants its sports
program to remain truly the ideal of athletic systems, they should
spend a little money to influence a graduate student or perhaps a
former Hopkins athlete working in the Baltimore area who have
the time to come out and help with the freshman teams. As the old
maxim goes,"If a job is worth doing, it is worth doing well."

Team Begins
Chess Drills
With the preliminary tournament to decide the positions of
each member of the team out of
the way, the chess club now gets
down to the serious business of
rounding into shape for their winter season.
George Hardman, president of
the club, who won the tourney,
said he was pleased with the turnout of twenty freshmen, but cautioned, "The team is green and
will need a great deal of conditioning. In order to get this experience
we have scheduled scrimmages
with the Naval Academy and Loyola College in the next two
weeks."
Hardman, who has been the star
of the team with his great board
work, defeated William Landis in
the Hopkins Open Chess tourney
by a 4%..'/ to 4-1 margin. Neither
man lost, but Landis tied twice
whereas Hardman was held even
only once.
Last year the team had only a
mediocre season, breaking even in
twenty matches, but the Jays finished third in the Maryland Chess
Federation.
Hardman, as the team's number
one board, has obtained individual
laurels. Last year he was one of
three people to draw with international grand master Samuel Reshevsky. Later in the year the
Hopkins ace defeated the Maryland State Champion in a non-title
bout and is looking for a return
go this year for the crown.
